form.preferredDefinition: The Self-Injurious Thoughts and Behaviors Interview (SITBI) is a structured interview that includes five modules assessing the presence, frequency, and characteristics of five types of self-injurious thoughts and behaviors: suicidal ideation, suicidal plans, suicidal gestures, suicidal attempts (including aborted and interrupted), and nonsuicidal self-injury. Each module begins with a screening question about lifetime presence of a self-injurious thought or behavior followed by items that measure age of onset, recent thoughts and behaviors, severity of thoughts and behaviors, probability of future behavior, and self-reported precipitants and functions of the behavior. In addition to the adult and adolescent sort form presented below, other versions of the SITBI are available: adult and adolescent long form, follow-up short form (prospective studies), and self-report.

question.questionText: Have you ever had thoughts of killing yourself? (suicidal_ideation_ever)
How old were you the first time you had thoughts of killing yourself? (suicidal_ideation_age_first_time)
How old were you the last time? (suicidal_ideation_age_last_time)
How many days in your life have you had thoughts of killing yourself? (Please give your best estimate) (suicidal_ideation_days_lifetime)
How many days in the past year? (suicidal_ideation_days_past_year)
How many days in the past month? (suicidal_ideation_days_past_month)
How many days in the past week? (suicidal_ideation_days_past_week)
Here is a scale we will use for a number of the upcoming questions: 04 SCALE: 0=not at all 1=a little bit 2=somewhat 3=very much 4=extremely (scale_640501)
On this scale of 0 to 4, at the worst point how intense were your thoughts of killing yourself? (suicidal_ideation_intensity_worst_point)
On the scale of 0 to 4, on average, how intense were these thoughts? (suicidal_ideation_intensity_average)
When you had thoughts of killing yourself, how long did they usually last? (suicidal_ideation_time_thinking_about)
On the scale of 0 to 4, what do you think the likelihood is that you will have a thought of killing yourself in the future? (suicidal_ideation_future_likelihood)
Suicide Plan (sp_640501)
Have you ever actually made a plan to kill yourself? (suicide_plan_ever)
How old were you the first time you made a suicide plan? (suicide_plan_age_first_time)
How old were you the last time? (suicide_plan_age_last_time)
How many days in your life have you made a suicide plan? (suicide_plan_days_lifetime)
How many days in the past year? (suicide_plan_days_past_year)
How many days in the past month? (suicide_plan_days_past_month)
How many days in the past week? (suicide_plan_days_past_week)
On the scale of 0 to 4, at the worst point, how seriously did you consider acting on the plan? (suicide_plan_seriousness_worst_point)
On the scale of 0 to 4, on average, how seriously have you considered acting on the plan(s)? (suicide_plan_seriousness_average)
When you had a plan(s), what method(s) did you think of using? (suicide_plan_method)
When you had a plan(s), what method(s) did you think of using? Other, specify (suicide_plan_method_other_specify)
When you had a plan(s), what method(s) did you think of using? Multiple methods, specify (suicide_plan_method_mulitplemethods_specify)
When you had a plan, how long did you think about it before either moving onto something else or acting on the plan? (suicide_plan_time_thinking_about)
When you had a plan(s), did you take steps to prepare to act on the plan(s)? (suicide_plan_steps)
What did you do? (suicide_plan_steps_specify)
On the scale of 0 to 4, what do you think the likelihood is that you will make a suicide plan in the future? (suicide_plan_future_likelihood)
Suicide Gesture (sg_640501)
Have you ever done something to lead someone to believe that you wanted to kill yourself when you really had no intention of doing so? (suicide_gesture_ever)
What have you done to lead someone to believe that you wanted to kill yourself when you really had no intention of doing so? (suicide_gesture_specify)
How old were you the first time you did something to lead someone to believe that you wanted to kill yourself when you really had no intention of doing so? (suicide_gesture_age_first_time)
How old were you the last time? (suicide_gesture_age_last_time)
How many times in your life have you done something to lead someone to believe that you wanted to kill yourself when really you had no intention of doing so? (suicide_gesture_times_lifetime)
How many times in the past year (suicide_gesture_times_past_year)
How many times in the past month? (suicide_gesture_times_past_month)
How many times in the past week? (suicide_gesture_times_past_week)

When you did something to lead someone to believe that you wanted to kill yourself when you really had no intention of doing so, how long did you think about it before doing it? (suicide_gesture_time_thinking_about)

On the scale of 0 to 4, what do you think the likelihood is that you will do something to lead someone to believe that you want to kill yourself when you really have no intention of doing so in the future? (suicide_gesture_future_likelihood)
Aborted Suicide Attempt (asa_640501)

Have you ever been close to killing yourself and at the last minute decided not to kill yourself? (Only if he/she did not sustain injuries see question below, mark 'yes' for this question) (suicide_attempt_aborted)
Did you sustain any physical injury? (suicide_attempt_aborted_injury)
What happened? (suicide_attempt_aborted_specify)
How many times in your life have you stopped yourself from attempting suicide right before you got hurt? (suicide_attempt_aborted_timesstopped_lifetime)
How many times in the past year? (suicide_attempt_aborted_timesstopped_pastyear)
How many times in the past month? (suicide_attempt_aborted_timesstopped_pastmonth)
How many times in the past week? (suicide_attempt_aborted_timesstopped_pastweek)
Interrupted Suicide Attempt (isa_640501)

Have you ever been very close to killing yourself and at the last minute someone or something else stopped you? (Only if he/she did not sustain injuries see question below, mark 'yes' for this question) (suicide_attempt_interrupted)
Did you sustain any physical injury? (suicide_attempt_interrupted_injury)
What happened? (suicide_attempt_interrupted_specify)
How many times in your life have you been close to killing yourself but were stopped by someone or something else right before you got hurt? (suicide_attempt_interrupted_timesstopped_lifetime)
How many times in the past year? (suicide_attempt_interrupted_timesstopped_pastyear)
How many times in the past month? (suicide_attempt_interrupted_timesstopped_pastmonth)
How many times in the past week? (suicide_attempt_interrupted_timesstopped_pastweek)
Suicide Attempt (sa_640501)
Have you ever made an actual attempt to kill yourself in which you had at least some intent to die? (suicide_attempt_ever)
How old were you the first time you made a suicide attempt? (suicide_attempt_age_first_time)
How old were you the last time? (suicide_attempt_age_last_time)
To your knowledge, what was the approximate date of the most recent attempt? Month (suicide_attempt_most_recent_month)
To your knowledge, what was the approximate date of the most recent attempt? Year (suicide_attempt_most_recent_year)
How many suicide attempts have you made in your lifetime? (suicide_attempt_times_lifetime)
How many in the past year? (suicide_attempt_times_past_year)
How many in the past month? (suicide_attempt_times_past_month)
How many in the past week? (suicide_attempt_times_past_week)
For your most recent suicide attempt, what method did you use? (suicide_attempt_method)
For your most recent suicide attempt, what method did you use? Other, specify (suicide_attempt_method_other_specify)
For your most recent suicide attempt, what method did you use? Multiple methods, specify (suicide_attempt_mulitplemethods_specify)
What were the circumstances that contributed most to your most recent attempt? (suicide_attempt_circumstances)
Other please describe: (other_640501)
What kind of injuries did you have as a result of this attempt? (suicide_attempt_injuries)
Regarding the most lethal attempt: (lethal_640501)
How old were you when you made the suicide attempt that caused you the most physical harm? (suicide_attempt_mostlethal_agefirsttime)
To your knowledge, what was the approximate date of the attempt that caused you the most physical harm? Month (suicide_attempt_mostlethal_month)
To your knowledge, what was the approximate date of the attempt that caused you the most physical harm? Year (suicide_attempt_mostlethal_year)
(Note to the data enterer: Please calculate how many days the most lethal suicide attempt was from the interview date.) (data_entering_640510)
What kind of injuries did you have as a result of this attempt? (suicide_attempt_mostlethal_injuries)
Is the most harmful attempt also the most recent? (suicide_attempt_mostlethal_mostrecent)
Regarding all your past suicide attempts: (all_attempts_640501)
Regarding all your past suicide attempts: How long did you usually think about suicide before making an attempt? (suicide_attempt_time_thinking_about)
On the scale of 0 to 4, what do you think the likelihood is that you will make a suicide attempt in the future? (suicide_attempt_future_likelihood)
Has anyone you have ever known died by suicide? (suicide_family_history)
Has anyone you have ever known died by suicide? If so, how many? (suicide_family_history_number)
What was/were their relationship(s) to you? (suicide_family_history_mother)
What was/were their relationship(s) to you? Other, specify (suicide_family_history_other_specify)
Has anyone you have ever known ever attempted suicide but lived? (suicide_family_history_survived)
Has anyone you have ever known ever attempted suicide but lived? If so, how many? (suicide_family_history_survived_number)
What was/were their relationship(s) to you? (suicide_family_history_survived_mother)
What was/were their relationship(s) to you? Other, specify (suicide_family_history_survived_otherspecify)

Thoughts of Nonsuicidal SelfInjury. People sometimes have thoughts about hurting themselves without wanting to die. Other times they actually do things to hurt themselves. Right now I'm going to ask you some questions about what some people think, and then I'll ask you about what some people do in a bit. (non_s_si_640501)
Have you ever had thoughts of purposely hurting yourself without wanting to die? (for example, cutting or burning) (nonsuicidal_self_injury_thoughts)
How old were you the first time you thought of purposely hurting yourself without wanting to die? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_age_first_time)
How old were you the last time? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_age_last_time)
How many days in your life have you had thoughts of purposely hurting yourself without wanting to die? (Please give your best estimate) (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_days_lifetime)
How many days in the past year? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_days_past_year)
How many days in the past month? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_days_past_month)
How many days in the past week? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_days_past_week)
On the scale of 0 to 4, at the worst point, how intense were your thoughts of purposely hurting yourself without wanting to die? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_intensity_worst)
On the scale of 0 to 4, on average, how intense were these thoughts? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_intensity_average)
What method did you think of using? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_method)

validValue.meaningText: burned your skin (i.e., with a cigarette, match, or other hot object)
validValue.description: burned your skin (i.e., with a cigarette, match, or other hot object)

validValue.meaningText: picked areas of your body to the point of drawing blood
validValue.description: picked areas of your body to the point of drawing blood

validValue.meaningText: scraped your skin to the point skin or nails of drawing blood
validValue.description: scraped your skin to the point skin or nails of drawing blood

question.questionText: What method did you think of using? other (specify) (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_method_otherspecify)
When you had these thoughts, how long did they usually last? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_duration)
On a scale of 0 to 4, what do you think the likelihood is that you will purposely hurt yourself without wanting to die in the future? (nonsuicidal_selfinjurythoughts_future_likelihood)
Nonsuicidal SelfInjury (nonsuicidal_640501)
Have you ever actually purposely hurt yourself without wanting to die? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_ever)
How old were you the first time you purposely hurt yourself without wanting to die? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_age_first_time)
How old were you the last time? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_age_last_time)

Now I'm going to go through a list of things that people sometimes purposely do to harm themselves without wanting to die. Please let me know which of these you've done: (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_method)

validValue.meaningText: burned your skin (i.e., with a cigarette, match, or other hot object)
validValue.description: burned your skin (i.e., with a cigarette, match, or other hot object)

validValue.meaningText: picked areas of your body to the point of drawing blood
validValue.description: picked areas of your body to the point of drawing blood

validValue.meaningText: scraped your skin to the point skin or nails of drawing blood
validValue.description: scraped your skin to the point skin or nails of drawing blood

question.questionText: Other, specify (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_method_otherspecify)
How many times in your life have you purposely hurt yourself without wanting to die? (Please give your best estimate) (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_times_lifetime)
How many times in the past year? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_times_past_year)
How many times in the past month? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_times_past_month)
How many times in the past week? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_times_past_week)
On average, how long have you thought of purposely hurting yourself without wanting to die before actually doing it? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_duration)
Have you ever received medical treatment for harm caused by purposely hurting yourself without wanting to die? (nonsuicidal_selfinjury_medical_treatment)
On a scale of 0 to 4, what do you think the likelihood is that you will purposely hurt yourself without wanting to die in the future? (hurt_purposely_640501)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Self-Injurious Thoughts and Behaviors Interview (SITBI) is a structured interview that includes five modules assessing the presence, frequency, and characteristics of five types of self-injurious thoughts and behaviors: suicidal ideation, suicidal plans, suicidal gestures, suicidal attempts (including aborted and interrupted), and nonsuicidal self-injury. Each module begins with a screening question about lifetime presence of a self-injurious thought or behavior followed by items that measure age of onset, recent thoughts and behaviors, severity of thoughts and behaviors, probability of future behavior, and self-reported precipitants and functions of the behavior. In addition to the adult and adolescent sort form presented below, other versions of the SITBI are available: adult and adolescent long form, follow-up short form (prospective studies), and self-report.

form.preferredDefinition: The Hopelessness Scale for Children (HSC) consists of 17 interviewer-administered true-false items. The HSC is modeled on the Beck Hopelessness Scale and captures feelings about the future, loss of motivation, and future expectations. "True" responses to the following items are scored as "1": For items 2, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, and 17, "True" responses are scored as "1." For items1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, and 16, "False" responses are scored as "1." The higher the total score, the greater the hopelessness for the future.

headerInstruction.text: Hopelessness Scale for Children (HSC): Instructions to be read to the child: These sentences are about how some kids feel about their lives. Your answers let us know about how kids feel about things. "I am going to read each sentence to you. I..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. I want to grow up because I think things will be better. (life_grow_up_better)
2. I might as well give up because I can't make things better for myself. (life_give_up)
3. When things are going badly, I know they won't be as bad all of the time. (life_going_badly)
4. I can imagine what my life will be like when I'm grown up. (imagine_life_grown_up)
5. I have enough time to finish the things I really want to do. (life_enough_time)
6. Someday, I will be good at doing the things that I really care about. (life_someday_good)
7. I will get more of the good things in life than most other kids. (life_more_good_things)
8. I don't have good luck and there's no reason to think I will when I grow up. (life_no_good_luck)
9. All I can see ahead of me are bad things, not good things. (life_see_badthings_ahead_nogood)
10. I don't think I will get what I really want. (life_dont_get_what_reallywant)
11. When I grow up, I think I will be happier than I am now. (life_growup_happier)
12. Things just won't work out the way I want them to. (life_wont_work_out)
13. I never get what I want, so it's dumb to want anything. (life_never_get_desires_dumb_towant)
14. I don't think I will have any real fun when I grow up. (life_no_real_fun_when_growup)
15. Tomorrow seems unclear and confusing to me. (life_tomorrow_unclear_confusing)
16. I will have more good times than bad times. (life_more_good_than_bad)
17. There's no use in really trying to get something I want because I probably won't get it. (life_no_use_trying)

Scoring:"True" responses to the following items are scored as "1" #2, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17 "False" responses to the following items are scored as "1" 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 16 The higher the score, the greater the hopelessness for the future. (scoring_640601)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Hopelessness Scale for Children (HSC) consists of 17 interviewer-administered true-false items. The HSC is modeled on the Beck Hopelessness Scale and captures feelings about the future, loss of motivation, and future expectations. "True" responses to the following items are scored as "1": For items 2, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, and 17, "True" responses are scored as "1." For items1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, and 16, "False" responses are scored as "1." The higher the total score, the greater the hopelessness for the future.

form.preferredDefinition: The Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire (BPAQ) consists of 29 self-administered items rated on a 5-point Likert scale. The BPAQ includes four subscales: Physical Aggression (items 1-9), Verbal Aggression (items 10-14), Anger (items 15-21), and Hostility (items 22-29.) The score for each scale is the sum or the ratings for its items. The two items (7 and 18) worded in the direction opposite to aggression are reverse-scored. The total score for aggression is the sum of these scale scores. Higher scores indicate higher aggressive behavior.

headerInstruction.text: BussPerry Aggression Questionnaire. Please select the following items in terms of how characteristic they are of you.

question.questionText: Once in a while I can't control the urge to strike another person. (aggression_urge_tostrike)
Given enough provocation, I may hit another person. (aggression_provocation_hit)
If somebody hits me, I hit back. (aggression_hit_back)
I get into fights a little more than the average person. (aggression_get_into_fights)
If I have to resort to violence to protect my rights, I will. (aggression_resort_toviolence)
There are people who pushed me so far that we came to blows. (aggression_pushed_to_blows)
I can think of no good reason for ever hitting a person (R). (aggression_no_reason_tohit)
I have threatened people I know. (aggression_threatened_people)
I have become so mad that I have broken things. (aggression_mad_broken_things)
I tell my friends openly when I disagree with them. (aggression_openly_disagree)
I often find myself disagreeing with people. (aggression_often_disagreeeing)
When people annoy me, I may tell them what I think of them. (aggression_tell_what_ithink)
I can't help getting into arguments when people disagree with me. (aggression_arguments_disagree)
My friends say that I'm somewhat argumentative. (anger_argumentative)
I flare up quickly but get over it quickly. (anger_flare_up_quickly)
When frustrated, I let my irritation show. (anger_frustrated_show_irritation)
I sometimes feel like a powder keg ready to explode. (anger_feel_ready_toexplode)
I am an eventempered person (R). (anger_eventempered)
Some of my friends think I'm a hothead. (anger_hothead)
Sometimes I fly off the handle for no good reason. (anger_fly_off_handle)
I have trouble controlling my temper. (hostility_trouble_controlling_temper)
I am sometimes eaten up with jealousy. (hostility_sometimes_jealous)
At times I feel I have gotten a raw deal out of life. (hostility_raw_deal_oflife)
Other people always seem to get the breaks. (hostility_others_get_breaks)
I wonder why sometimes I feel so bitter about things. (hostilitybitter)
I know that "friends" talk about me behind my back. (hostility_friends_talk_aboutme)
I am suspicious of overly friendly strangers. (hostility_suspicious_of_strangers)
I sometimes feel that people are laughing at me behind me back. (hostility_people_laughing_atme)
When people are especially nice, I wonder what they want. (hostility_people_nice_iwonder)

Scoring: Physical Aggression subscale: items 19. Verbal Aggression subscale: items 1014. Anger subscale: items 1521. Hostility subscale: items 2229. The score for each scale is the sum or the ratings for its items. The two items (7 and 18) worded in the direction opposite to aggression are reversescored. The total score for aggression is the sum of these scale scores. Higher scores indicate higher aggressive behavior. (scoring_640701)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire (BPAQ) consists of 29 self-administered items rated on a 5-point Likert scale. The BPAQ includes four subscales: Physical Aggression (items 1-9), Verbal Aggression (items 10-14), Anger (items 15-21), and Hostility (items 22-29.) The score for each scale is the sum or the ratings for its items. The two items (7 and 18) worded in the direction opposite to aggression are reverse-scored. The total score for aggression is the sum of these scale scores. Higher scores indicate higher aggressive behavior.

form.preferredDefinition: The Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) is a brief, self-administered questionnaire that captures the respondent's perception of his or her current insomnia. The ISI has been used with adolescents and adults. The ISI includes seven items that assess severity of sleep onset, sleep maintenance, and early morning awakening problems; sleep dissatisfaction; interference of sleep difficulties with daytime functioning; noticeability of sleep problems by others; and distress caused by the sleep difficulties. Each item is rated on a 4-point Likert scale, and the total score ranges from 0 to 28. A higher score suggests more severe insomnia.

question.questionText: Insomnia Severity Index:For each question, please CIRCLE the number that best describes your answer. Please rate the CURRENT (i.e. LAST 2 WEEKS) SEVERITY of your insomnia problem(s). (info_640801)
1. Difficulty falling asleep (insomnia_falling_asleep)
2. Difficulty staying asleep (insomnia_staying_asleep)
3. Problems waking up too early (insomnia_waking_up_early)
4. How SATISFIED/DISSATISFIED are you with your CURRENT sleep pattern? (insomnia_satisfieddissatisfied_sleep_pattern)
5. How NOTICEABLE to others do you think your sleep problem is in terms of impairing the quality of your life? (insomnia_noticeable_impairing_qol)
6. How WORRIED/DISTRESSED are you about your current sleep problem? (insomnia_worried_distressed)

7 To what extent do you consider your sleep problem to INTERFERE with your daily functioning (e.g. daytime fatigue, mood, ability to function at work/daily chores, concentration, memory, mood, etc.) CURRENTLY? (insomnia_interfere_dailyfunctioning)

Guidelines for Scoring/Interpretation: Add the scores for all seven items (questions 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 +6 + 7) = _______ your total score Total score categories: 07 = No clinically significant insomnia814 = Subthreshold insomnia1521 = Clinical insomnia (moderate severity)2228 = Clinical insomnia (severe) (scoring_640801)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) is a brief, self-administered questionnaire that captures the respondent's perception of his or her current insomnia. The ISI has been used with adolescents and adults. The ISI includes seven items that assess severity of sleep onset, sleep maintenance, and early morning awakening problems; sleep dissatisfaction; interference of sleep difficulties with daytime functioning; noticeability of sleep problems by others; and distress caused by the sleep difficulties. Each item is rated on a 4-point Likert scale, and the total score ranges from 0 to 28. A higher score suggests more severe insomnia.

form.longName: PhenX PX640901 - Deterrents To Suicide Clinical Child
form.preferredDefinition: The Reasons for Living for Adolescents (RFL-A) inventory includes 32 self-report items that measure the adolescent respondent's various reasons for living and their attitudes about living versus committing suicide. The RFL-A includes subscales for family alliance, suicide-related concerns, self-acceptance, peer-acceptance and support, and future optimism. Each item is rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 ("not at all important") to 6 ("extremely important"). Ratings for each subscale are constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items in the subscale. The total RFLA score is constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items.

headerInstruction.text: Reasons for Living for Adolescents: The questionnaire lists specific reasons that people sometimes have for not committing suicide, if the thought were to occur to them or if someone were to suggest it to them. Please read each statement caref..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. Whenever I have a problem, I can turn to my family for support or advice. (suicide_problem_support_advice)
2. It would be painful and frightening to take my own life. (suicide_painful_frightening)
3. I accept myself for what I am. (suicide_accept_myself)
4. I have a lot to look forward to as I grow older. (suicide_grow_older)
5. My friends stand by me whenever I have a problem. (suicide_friends_stand_byme)
6. I feel loved and accepted by my close friends. (suicide_loved_accepted)
7. I feel emotionally close to my family. (suicide_emotionally_close_family)
8. I am afraid to die, so I would not consider killing myself. (suicide_afraid_to_die)
9. I like myself just the way I am. (suicide_like_myself)
10. My friends care a lot about me. (suicide_friends_care)
11. I would like to accomplish my plans or goals in the future. (suicide_plans_future)
12. My family takes the time to listen to my experiences at school, work, or home. (suicide_family_listens)
13. I expect many good things to happen to me in the future. (suicide_expect_good_future)
14. I am satisfied with myself. (suicide_satisfied)
15. I am hopeful about my plans or goals for the future. (suicide_hopefully_future)
16. I believe my friends appreciate me when I am with them. (suicide_friends_appreciateme)
17. I enjoy being with my family. (suicide_enjoy_family)
18. I feel that I am an OK person. (suicide_feel_ok)
19. I expect to be successful in the future. (suicide_expect_success)
20. The thought of killing myself scares me. (suicide_scares_me)
21. I am afraid of using any method to kill myself. (suicide_afraid_of_methods)
22. I can count on my friends to help if I have a problem. (suicide_count_onfriends)
23. Most of the time, my family encourages and supports my plans or goals. (suicide_family_support)
24. My family cares about the way I feel. (suicide_family_cares_feelings)
25. My future looks quite hopeful and promising. (suicide_future_hopeful_promising)
26. I am afraid of killing myself. (suicide_afraid_of_killing)
27. My friends accept me for what I really am. (suicide_friends_acceptme)
28. I have many future plans I am looking forward to carrying out in the future. (suicide_future_plans)
29. I feel good about myself. (suicide_feel_good)
30. My family cares a lot about what would happen to me. (suicide_family_cares_whathappens)
31. I am happy with myself. (suicide_happy_with_self)
32. I would be frightened or afraid to make plans for killing myself. (suicide_frightened_to_makeplans)

Scoring: Family Alliance (FA) Scale (7 items) **Calculate mean rating for items: 1, 7, 12, 17, 23, 24, and 30. Suiciderelated Concerns (SRC) Scale (6 items)**Calculate mean rating for items: 2, 8, 20, 21, 26, and 32.SelfAcceptance (SA) Scale (6 items)**Calculate mean rating for items: 3, 9, 14, 18, 29, and 31.PeerAcceptance and Support (PAS) Scale (6 items)**Calculate mean rating for items: 5, 6, 10, 15, 22, and 27.Future Optimism (FO) Scale (7 items)**Calculate mean rating for items: 4, 11, 13, 15, 19, 25, and 28.Total Score**Calculate mean rating for items 1 to 32. (scoring_640901)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Reasons for Living for Adolescents (RFL-A) inventory includes 32 self-report items that measure the adolescent respondent's various reasons for living and their attitudes about living versus committing suicide. The RFL-A includes subscales for family alliance, suicide-related concerns, self-acceptance, peer-acceptance and support, and future optimism. Each item is rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 ("not at all important") to 6 ("extremely important"). Ratings for each subscale are constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items in the subscale. The total RFLA score is constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items.

form.longName: PhenX PX640902 - Deterrents To Suicide Clinical Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Reasons for Living (RFL) inventory includes 48 self-report items that measures the respondent's various reasons for living and their attitudes about living versus attempting or committing suicide. The RFL includes subscales for survival and coping beliefs, responsibility to family, child-related concerns, fear of suicide, fear of social disapproval, and moral objections. Each item is rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 ("not at all important") to 6 ("extremely important"). Ratings on the individual items are added together to give scores for individual subscales or to obtain an overall score for the whole inventory. Higher scores reflect greater reasons for living.

headerInstruction.text: Reasons for Living. INSTRUCTIONS: Many people have thought of suicide at least once. Others have never considered it. Whether you have considered it or not, we are interested in the reasons you would have for not committing suicide if the thou..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. I have a responsibility and commitment to my family (suicide_responsibility_to_family)
2. I believe I can learn to adjust or cope with my problems (suicide_cope_with_problems)
3. I would not want people to think I did not have control over my life (suicide_control_over_life)
4. I have a desire to live (suicide_desire_to_live)
5. I believe only God has the right to end a life (suicide_right_to_end_life)
6. I am afraid of death (suicide_afraid_of_death)
7. My family might believe I did not love them (suicide_family_love)
8. I do not believe that things get miserable or hopeless enough that I would rather be dead (suicide_not_miserable_enough)
9. My family depends upon me and needs me (suicide_family_needs)
10. I do not want to die (suicide_want_to_die)
11. I want to watch my children as they grow (suicide_children_grow)
12. Life is all we have and is better than nothing (suicide_better_than_nothing)
13. I have future plans I am looking forward to carrying out (suicide_future_plans_2)
14. No matter how badly I feel, I know that it will not last (suicide_will_not_last)
15. I am afraid of the unknown (suicide_afraid_of_unknown)
16. I love and enjoy my family too much and could not leave them (enjoy_family_640902)
17. I want to experience all that life has to offer and there are many experiences I haven't had yet which I want to have (suicide_experience_life)
18. I am afraid that my method of killing myself would fail (suicide_killing_method_fail)
19. I care enough about myself to live (suicide_care_to_live)
20. Life is too beautiful and precious to end it (suicide_life_is_beautiful)
21. It would not be fair to leave the children for others to take care of (suicide_leave_children_for_others)
22. I believe I can find other solutions to my problems (suicide_find_solutions_to_problems)
23. I am afraid of going to hell (suicide_afraid_of_hell)
24. I have a love of life (suicide_love_of_life)
25. I am too stable to kill myself (suicide_stable)
26. I am a coward and do not have the guts to do it (suicide_coward)
27. My religious beliefs forbid it (suicide_religious_beliefs_forbid)
28. The effect on my children could be harmful (suicide_effect_on_children)
29. I am curious about what will happen in the future (suicide_curious_about_future)
30. It would hurt my family too much and I would not want them to suffer (suicide_hurt_family)
31. I am concerned about what others would think of me (suicide_concerned_about_others)
32. I believe everything has a way of working out for the best (suicide_working_out)
33. I could not decide where, when, and how to do it (suicide_could_not_decide)
34. I consider it morally wrong (suicide_morally_wrong)
35. I still have many things left to do (suicide_things_left)
36. I have the courage to face life (suicide_courage_to_face_life)
37. I am happy and content with my life (suicide_happy_with_life)
38. I am afraid of the actual "act" of killing myself (the pain blood violence) (afraid_of_killing)
39. I believe killing myself would not really accomplish or solve anything (suicide_not_solve_anything)
40. I have hope that things will improve and the future will be happier (suicide_things_will_improve)
41. Other people would think I am weak and selfish (suicide_other_think_weak)
42. I have an inner drive to survive (suicide_drive_to_survive)
43. I would not want people to think I did not have control over my life. (control_640902)
44. I believe I can find a purpose in life, a reason to live (suicide_find_reason_to_live)
45. I see no reason to hurry death along (suicide_no_reason_death)
46. I am so inept that my method would not work (suicide_inept_not_work)
47. I would not want my family to feel guilty afterwards (suicide_family_feel_guilty)
48. I would not want my family to think I was selfish or a coward (suicide_family_think_selfish)

Scoring: Survival and Coping Beliefs: items 124. Responsibility to Family: items 2531. ChildRelated Concerns: items 3234. Fear of Suicide: items 3541. Fear of Social Disapproval: items 4244. Moral Objections: items 4548. Ratings on the individual items are added together to give scores for individual subscales or to obtain an overall score for the whole inventory. Higher scores reflect greater reasons for living. (scoring_640902)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Reasons for Living (RFL) inventory includes 48 self-report items that measures the respondent's various reasons for living and their attitudes about living versus attempting or committing suicide. The RFL includes subscales for survival and coping beliefs, responsibility to family, child-related concerns, fear of suicide, fear of social disapproval, and moral objections. Each item is rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 ("not at all important") to 6 ("extremely important"). Ratings on the individual items are added together to give scores for individual subscales or to obtain an overall score for the whole inventory. Higher scores reflect greater reasons for living.

form.longName: PhenX PX640903 - Deterrents To Suicide Epidemiology
form.preferredDefinition: The Attitudes Towards Suicide Scale (ATTS) includes 37 self-report items that measure the respondent's attitudes about committing suicide. The ATTS includes a section about suicide expressions among family and friends, a section on attitudes and common beliefs about suicide, and a section about the respondent's suicidal expressions. Each item is rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 ("strongly agree") to 5 ("strongly disagree"). Ratings for each subscale are constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items in the subscale. The total ATTS inventory score is constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items.

headerInstruction.text: Attitudes Towards Suicide Scale : The following questions concern your opinion about suicide. Please select the alternative that you find is in best accordance with your opinion. There are no "right" or "wrong" answers!

question.questionText: It is always possible to help a person with suicidal thoughts (suicide_help_with_suicidal_thoughts)
Suicide can never be justified (suicide_never_justified)
Taking one's own life is among one of the worst things to do to one's relatives (suicide_worst_for_relatives)
Most suicide attempts are impulsive actions (by nature) (suicide_impulsive_actions)
Suicide is an acceptable means to terminate an incurable disease (suicide_acceptable_for_incurable_disease)
Once a person has made up his/her mind about taking his/her own life, no one can stop him/her (suicide_can_stop)
Many suicide attempts are made because of revenge or to punish someone else (suicide_punish_someone_else)
People who take their own lives are usually mentally ill (suicide_mentally_ill)
It is a human duty to try to stop someone from dying by suicide (suicide_duty_to_stop)
When a person dies by suicide, it is something that he/she has considered for a long time (suicide_considered_long_time)
There is a risk of evoking suicidal thoughts in a person's mind if you ask about it (suicide_risk_evoking_suicidal_thoughts)
People who make suicidal threats seldom complete suicide (suicide_threats_seldom_complete)
Suicide is a subject that one should not talk about (suicide_should_not_talk_about)
Loneliness could for me be a reason to take my life (suicide_loneliness_a_reason)
Almost everyone has at one time or another thought about suicide (suicide_everyone_thought_about_suicide)
There may be situations where the only reasonable resolution is suicide (suicide_only_resolution)
I could say that I would take my life without actually meaning it (suicide_say_without_meaning_it)
Suicide can sometimes be a relief for those involved (suicide_relief_for_those_involved)
Suicides among young people are particularly puzzling since they have everything to live for (suicide_young_to_live_for)
I would consider the possibility of taking my life if I were to suffer from a severe, incurable disease (suicide_possibility_suffer_incurable_disease)
A person once they have suicidal thoughts will never let them go (suicide_thoughts_never_let_go)
Suicide happens without warning (suicide_without_warning)
Most people avoid talking about suicide (suicide_avoid_talking)
If someone wants to commit suicide it is their business, and we should not interfere (suicide_not_interfere)
It is mainly loneliness that drives people to suicide (suicide_mainly_loneliness)
A suicide attempt is essentially a cry for help (suicide_cry_for_help)
On the whole, I do not understand how people can take their lives (suicide_understand)
Usually relatives have no idea about what is going on when a person is thinking of suicide (suicide_relatives_idea_about_suicide)
A person suffering from a severe, incurable disease expressing wishes to die should get that help to do so (suicide_should_get_help)
I am prepared to help a person in a suicidal crisis by making contact (suicide_prepared_to_help)
Anybody can die by suicide (suicide_can_die)
I can understand that people suffering from a severe, incurable disease die by suicide (suicide_understand_incurable_disease_suicide)
People who talk about suicide do not die by suicide (suicide_talk_suicide_not_die)
People do have the right to take their own lives (suicide_right)
Most suicide attempts are caused by conflicts with a close person (suicide_conflicts_with_close_person)
I would like to get help to take my own life if I were to suffer from a severe, incurable disease (suicide_get_help_incurable_disease)
Suicide can be prevented (suicide_prevented)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Attitudes Towards Suicide Scale (ATTS) includes 37 self-report items that measure the respondent's attitudes about committing suicide. The ATTS includes a section about suicide expressions among family and friends, a section on attitudes and common beliefs about suicide, and a section about the respondent's suicidal expressions. Each item is rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 ("strongly agree") to 5 ("strongly disagree"). Ratings for each subscale are constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items in the subscale. The total ATTS inventory score is constructed by calculating the mean rating for all items.

form.longName: PhenX PX641001 - Access To Lethal Means
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes three questions from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) 2004 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System State (BRFSS) Questionnaire. These questions capture whether firearms are present in the home and, if so, how they are stored (e.g., loaded and unlocked).

question.questionText: The next questions are about firearms. We are asking these in a health survey because of our interest in firearmrelated injuries. Please include weapons such as pistols, shotguns, and rifles but not BB guns, starter pistols, or guns that cannot fire. Include those kept in a garage, outdoor storage area, or motor vehicle. (info_641001)
Are any firearms kept in or around your home? (firearms_in_home)

validValue.meaningText: Don't know/Not sure [go to closing statement]
validValue.description: Don't know/Not sure [go to closing statement]

question.questionText: Are any of these firearms now loaded? (firearms_loaded)

validValue.meaningText: Don't know/Not sure [go to closing statement]
validValue.description: Don't know/Not sure [go to closing statement]

question.questionText: Are any of these loaded firearms also unlocked? By unlocked, we mean you do not need a key or combination to get the gun or to fire it. We don't count a safety as a lock. (loaded_firearms_unlocked)

Closing statement. Please read: That's my last question. Everyone's answers will be combined to give us information about the health practices of people in this state. Thank you very much for your time and cooperation. (closing_641001)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes three questions from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) 2004 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System State (BRFSS) Questionnaire. These questions capture whether firearms are present in the home and, if so, how they are stored (e.g., loaded and unlocked).
